unit_learning_outcomes.description: Develop self-awareness skills by identifying and setting targets, and applying time management
Solve problems by comparing alternative interpretations of neuroscience data and formulating new explanations
Critically analyse the key concepts of biopsychology and learning
Use electronic databases to search for papers on relevant topics.
Demonstrate written and oral communication skills, including through participation in class discussions
Demonstrate a general understanding of the principles and mechanisms of behavioural neuroscience, neurophysiology, neuropharmacology and learning.

assessments.description: Students complete a 1500 word research report on a behavioural experiment.
Final examination held within the University’s formal exam period, in accordance with relevant requirements
Regular online quizzes testing unit content

data.description: This unit is designed to give students a basic knowledge of central neuronal mechanisms underlying fundamental behaviours and how these behaviours are modified through experience (learning). Half of the program describes the cytoarchitecture of central and peripheral neurons; the physiological and ionic bases of axonal and synaptic transmission; the overall anatomical organisation of the mammalian brain, and; sensory processing. These topics are followed by discussion on the central mechanisms underlying mammalian behaviours, such as motivation and psychopathology. The other half of the program provides a basic understanding of diverse phenomena in learning and behaviour, including classical conditioning and operant conditioning.
data.title: Biopsychology and Learning
